en: Interview with Stephen Lyn Bales, Gatlinburg native, naturalist and writer, who speaks of his experiences of growing up in the Gatlinburg area.  Bales reflects on his childhood and ancestral ties to Gatlinburg, as well as the emotional impact of the Chimney Tops 2 Wildfires of 2016. This is a representative quote from the interview: "All I really lost are the fountainhead of my memories, everything.  But I still have the memories.  And now they’ve been recorded."

Interview with Stephen Lyn Bales, 2021-10-13 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Interview with Stephen Lyn Bales, 2021-10-13 -- Gatlinburg
You grew up in Gatlinburg and then came to Knoxville when you were goinig to college, right?
Could you tell us a little bit about your family heritage background?
So did you grow up with an outdoor tradition? Were you always outdoors? Did you enjoy the natural area?
Did you do a lot of camping in your youth? Was that a part of your experience?
And I'm just wondering, from you perspective as a naturalist, your reflections on the changes in Sevier County and that part of the world.
Tremendous changes to the physical built environment, correct?
Can you remember the days leading up to the fires, or maybe that summer?
You mentioned other buildings on your family property, were those leveled, too? Were those burned as well?
So it was a very dry fall, and many people in Knoxville recall smelling fires through that late summer and early fall. Do you remember any of that?

And as a naturalist, have you had occasion to think about the natural environment and the place of wildfires in the natural environment and this particular tragedy and just sort of contemplate that as a natural sort of experience or not?
Have you had occasion to make other visits back to your, back to the property that your family owned, that you know, where the house was? Do you know have they rebuilt or anything?
Were there fires growing up occassionally? Were there wild fires in the area?
It must have been a really emotional time waiting for word those several days.

Have you, have you had occasion to speak with other close friends or, or family in addition to your sister who, who had connections to the area? And if so, any thoughts about their experiences, how they were similar to your own or different from your own or?
Is there anything else you'd like to add or any other thoughts or any topics you'd like to talk about that I haven't touched on?
